awd_titl_txt: Mechanisms of Proton Transport in Ionic Liquids: Grotthuss vs Vehicular
awd_abstract_narration:
Professors Sokolov and Paddison from the University of Tennessee combine experimental and computational studies of ionic liquids to unravel important requirements for elucidating highly efficient proton transport mechanisms.  Protons are hydrogen atoms that are missing their single electron, and therefore positively charged. Proton motion is vital for the function of various biological systems (for example, energy production and nerve function) and is important in many technological applications, such as energy conversion and storage.  Ionic liquids are substances in which the constituent molecules are themselves charged. For example, a neutral molecule can release a proton (+1 electrical charge) from its structure, thus rendering itself a negatively charged (-1) ion.   Ionic liquids are a promising class of substances for energy technology applications because they can facilitate very fast transport of protons (in other words they can be highly electrically conductive).     Profs.  Sokolov and Paddison are seeking to distinguish the various mechanisms of proton transport.  One these, the "Grotthuss mechanism" leads to high conductivity because it arises from the cooperative motion of several protons at a time.   Experimental identification of this mechanism and understanding its occurrence relative to different kinds of molecular structures would greatly advance our ability to design molecules for ionic liquid applications.

The overarching goal of this proposal is to develop a fundamental molecular level understanding of the chemical and structural aspects that control proton transport in protic ionic liquids. The PIs expect to reveal systems with extremely low energy barriers for proton transfer by choosing the right combination of proton acceptors and proton donors. In addition, they focus on analysis of correlated proton dynamics in search for experimental evidences of the collective Grotthuss-like proton transfer mechanism. To achieve these goals the PIs employ broadband dielectric and light scattering spectroscopies, neutron scattering, rheology, and NMR studies, all in tight connection with density function theory (DFT) based electronic structure calculations and ab-initio molecular dynamics simulations. The broader impact of this work includes significant societal benefits from a predictive understanding of proton transport mechanisms, as well as opportunity for training students and postdoctoral associates in advanced experiments and complex simulations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Proton transport plays a crucial role in many biochemical processes, and features importantly in various clean energy technologies. Controlling proton transport will significantly improve efficiency of these technologies. However, detailed molecular-level understanding of the mechanisms controlling proton transport remains elusive. In particular, conditions for the most efficient proton transport mechanism, collective chain-like proton transfer (historically referred to as the Grotthuss mechanism) remain a puzzle.

This project focused on pursuing a fundamental understanding of the proton transfer mechanism and correlated proton dynamics in protic ionic liquids (PILs). Our combined experimental and computational studies determined that phosphoric acid has the lowest energy barrier for a proton transfer, and mixtures with it and various bases do not significantly decrease the energy barrier. We also discovered that protons in phosphoric acid and its aqueous solutions move by very short jumps ~0.5-0.7 Å (see the image of trajectory). These jumps, however, are very fast due to the relatively low energy barriers. In contrast, our results revealed that proton conductivity in aqueous sulfuric acid solutions is dominated by a vehicular mechanism where the proton moves with a molecule. The vehicle mechanism is the least efficient proton transport. These results explain why phosphoric acid is the best known intrinsic proton conductor.

Special attention of the project was paid to correlated collective proton motions in PILs. Our analysis revealed that proton transfer events in phosphoric acid are indeed correlated. However, this collective transport actually suppresses the ionic conductivity. This is in contrast to the expected enhancement of conductivity via a Grotthuss mechanism. Based on these results, and earlier studies of ionic liquids, we concluded that ionic correlations always lead to suppression of conductivity in bulk liquids. This conclusion has strong implications for our general understanding of ion transport in liquids. Thus, the understanding and insights acquired during this award are instrumental in the design of novel proton conducting materials for clean energy generation and conversion.

In addition to these scientific achievements, this funding by the NSF significantly contributed to the development of human resources and education. Three graduate students and one postdoctoral associate (female) were actively involved in this research. One of the students successfully defended his thesis in 2020, and the second one will graduate in the Fall of 2021. The postdoctoral associate who worked on this project successfully transitioned to an industrial position.

We also paid attention to working with high school students. For several years during each summer before the pandemic, Dr. Sokolov presented a lecture to about 100 high school students attending the Governor’s summer school at the University of Tennessee. This school attracts the best high-school students from the entire state of Tennessee.
